Real Experiences

Expat Stories

No BS. Real stories from people actually living here - the good, the bad, and the "why didn't anyone tell me this before I moved?"

Jake Donovan
Portland, Oregon, USA ‚Ä¢ Software Developer
12 min read
Palermo Soho2 years in BANear Plaza Serrano
"I came for three months and stayed for two years. The first month I was like 'what the hell is a blue dollar?' Now I can explain it to newcomers in my sleep."

Jake arrived as a digital nomad in 2022, thinking he'd bounce around South America. Two years later, he's still in the same apartment on Costa Rica Street, has a local girlfriend, and has learned that 'ma√±ana' doesn't always mean tomorrow.

The Good
  • ‚Ä¢ I can actually afford to live alone in a nice apartment
  • ‚Ä¢ The tech community here is surprisingly tight-knit
  • ‚Ä¢ Nobody judges you for having wine with lunch
  • ‚Ä¢ La Viruta on Wednesday nights - life-changing
The Bad
  • ‚Ä¢ The garant√≠a system is actual hell. I needed a local friend to co-sign for my apartment
  • ‚Ä¢ Inflation means you're constantly doing mental math
  • ‚Ä¢ Good luck getting anything done between 1-4pm
The Reality

You will gain weight. The food is incredible and cheap. The gym culture exists but it's not the same pressure as the US. I've accepted my 'empanada body'.

What I Wish I Knew Before Moving

  • ‚ÜíBring more cash than you think. The blue dollar rate is real and it matters.
  • ‚ÜíLearn Spanish BEFORE you come. 'I can learn there' is a cute idea that will make your first 6 months harder.
  • ‚ÜíThe European architecture tricks you. This is still Latin America. Things break. Plans change.

My Monthly Budget (USD)

Rent:$650 USD (2BR in Palermo Soho, splitting with girlfriend)
Utilities:$40 USD (varies wildly with inflation)
Food:$400 USD (eating out 3-4x/week)
Coworking:$120 USD (WeWork membership)
Transport:$30 USD (SUBE card + occasional Ubers)
Total:~$1,240/month

Where I Hang Out

  • üìçLa Biela in Recoleta for coffee and people-watching
  • üìçMercado de San Telmo on Sundays (get the chorip√°n)
  • üìçEl Boliche de Dario for the best empanadas
  • üìçAny park with mate and friends on weekends

My Biggest Mistake (So You Don't Make It)

I tried to open a bank account in my first month. Don't. Just use Western Union, bring cash, or use crypto. The banking system here is not designed for you and you don't need it anyway.

Remote tech work from cafesTango lessons at La VirutaWeekend trips to TigreBuilding a local friend group
Klaus & Ingrid Hoffmann
Munich, Germany ‚Ä¢ Retired Engineer & Teacher
15 min read
Recoleta3 years in BAAvenida Callao near Recoleta Cemetery
"Our German pension gives us a lifestyle here we could never afford in Munich. But the healthcare system took us a year to figure out."

Klaus and Ingrid moved to Buenos Aires at 68 and 65, chasing better weather and lower costs. They've navigated the healthcare maze, dealt with a broken hip, and learned that Argentine dinner time is non-negotiable.

The Good
  • ‚Ä¢ Our apartment has a terrace with a view. In Munich, we'd be in a studio.
  • ‚Ä¢ The private healthcare (OSDE) is excellent and affordable
  • ‚Ä¢ The cafe culture suits us perfectly
  • ‚Ä¢ We've made more friends here in 3 years than 20 in Munich
The Bad
  • ‚Ä¢ The garant√≠a was impossible. We had to pay 6 months upfront
  • ‚Ä¢ Paperwork. So much paperwork. Everything requires a DNI
  • ‚Ä¢ When Ingrid broke her hip, navigating the hospital system in Spanish was terrifying
The Reality

You will eat dinner at 10pm. There is no alternative. We tried to find restaurants that opened at 7pm. They don't exist or they're tourist traps. We adapted. Now we have 'merienda' at 5pm like locals.

What I Wish I Knew Before Moving

  • ‚ÜíGet a good immigration lawyer. The retirement visa process is straightforward but the bureaucracy is not.
  • ‚ÜíBring original birth certificates, marriage certificates, everything. Apostilled.
  • ‚ÜíThe 'European feel' is only skin deep. Underneath, this is a different world.

My Monthly Budget (USD)

Rent:$900 USD (2BR with terrace, full service)
Utilities:$60 USD
Food:$500 USD (mostly cooking, nice dinners out)
Healthcare:$300 USD (OSDE 310 plan for both)
Transport:$100 USD (mostly taxis - we're not taking the subway at our age)
Total:~$1,860/month

Where I Hang Out

  • üìçLa Biela for coffee and pastries
  • üìçThe parks in Palermo for walking
  • üìçTeatro Col√≥n for opera and concerts
  • üìçOur building's terrace with wine and neighbors

My Biggest Mistake (So You Don't Make It)

We didn't realize how important the DNI is. We tried to do everything with our passport for the first 6 months. Get your temporary residency started immediately, then get your DNI. Everything is easier with a DNI.

Retirement visa processHealthcare qualityBuilding social life in 60sCost of living comparison
Marisol Vega
Miami, USA (Cuban-American) ‚Ä¢ Marketing Manager
11 min read
Belgrano1.5 years in BACalle Echeverr√≠a near Chinatown
"I moved here with my Argentine boyfriend. Being Latina, I thought I'd adapt easily. I was wrong. Miami Cuban is not the same as Porte√±o."

Marisol followed her boyfriend home after 3 years of long-distance. She thought her Spanish and Latin background would make it easy. Instead, she struggled with the 'Porte√±o' attitude, the economic uncertainty, and finding work.

The Good
  • ‚Ä¢ Living with my partner finally, after years of long-distance
  • ‚Ä¢ The food reminds me of my abuela's cooking sometimes
  • ‚Ä¢ Weekend asados with his family are everything
  • ‚Ä¢ I found a remote job with a US company - game changer
The Bad
  • ‚Ä¢ The 'Porte√±o' superiority complex is real. They think they're the Europeans of South America
  • ‚Ä¢ Finding a job that pays in dollars took 8 months
  • ‚Ä¢ His family still asks when we're having kids. Every. Sunday.
The Reality

The inflation is psychological warfare. You never know what anything costs. You develop this hoarding instinct - buy it now because it'll be more expensive tomorrow. I have 6 bottles of my favorite shampoo.

What I Wish I Knew Before Moving

  • ‚ÜíYour Spanish being 'good' isn't enough. Porte√±o slang is its own language.
  • ‚ÜíThe job market is brutal if you need pesos. Start looking for remote work before you move.
  • ‚ÜíDating a local helps but also complicates everything. You're not just dating him, you're dating his entire family.

My Monthly Budget (USD)

Rent:$0 (living with partner, he owns the apartment)
Utilities:$50 USD (my contribution)
Food:$300 USD (my share of groceries and eating out)
Therapy:$200 USD (yes, really, everyone has a therapist here)
Transport:$40 USD
Total:~$590/month (lucky situation)

Where I Hang Out

  • üìçBarrio Chino for Asian groceries and bubble tea
  • üìçLas Ca√±itas for drinks with other expat friends
  • üìçMy boyfriend's family house in Olivos for Sunday asado
  • üìçAny feria artesanal for shopping

My Biggest Mistake (So You Don't Make It)

I thought I could just 'find a local job.' I applied to 40+ positions. The salaries were insulting - like $800 USD/month for a senior marketing role. I finally got a remote US job and now I live like a queen here. Don't move without dollar income.

Moving with a local partnerJob search realityCultural adaptationRemote work transition
Tom Brennan
Dublin, Ireland ‚Ä¢ UX Designer
10 min read
Villa Crespo8 months in BAMalabia near the outlet shops
"The 'ma√±ana' culture nearly broke me. I'm Irish, we're direct, we get things done. Here, everything is 'tranqui' until it's an emergency."

Tom moved to Buenos Aires thinking he'd found the perfect remote work setup. Instead, he spent his first three months in a Kafkaesque nightmare of delayed deliveries, missed appointments, and learning that 'yes' often means 'maybe' or even 'no.'

The Good
  • ‚Ä¢ The cost of living is absurdly good for someone with European salary
  • ‚Ä¢ The steak. My god, the steak.
  • ‚Ä¢ Once you make friends, they're friends for life
  • ‚Ä¢ The city is beautiful in a way that still makes me stop and stare
The Bad
  • ‚Ä¢ The internet went out for 3 days and my landlord said 'tranqui, it'll be fixed when it's fixed'
  • ‚Ä¢ Delivery times are fictional. 'It arrives Tuesday' means 'sometime this month hopefully'
  • ‚Ä¢ Nobody tells you no directly. You have to learn to read between the lines
The Reality

I had to learn to lower my expectations. Things that would take a day in Dublin take a week here. Things that would take a week take a month. You either adapt or you go insane. I'm still working on the adaptation.

What I Wish I Knew Before Moving

  • ‚ÜíBring a VPN that works. The internet restrictions here are annoying.
  • ‚ÜíGet a local SIM immediately. WhatsApp is the operating system of Argentina.
  • ‚ÜíDon't expect things to work the way they do at home. They don't. They won't.

My Monthly Budget (USD)

Rent:$550 USD (studio in Villa Crespo)
Utilities:$35 USD
Food:$350 USD (cooking mostly, steak splurges)
Coworking:$80 USD (local coworking space)
Therapy:$150 USD (I need it here)
Transport:$25 USD
Total:~$1,190/month

Where I Hang Out

  • üìçThe Irish pubs when I need to hear English and feel at home
  • üìçDon Julio when someone else is paying
  • üìçMy rooftop for mate and complaining with other expats
  • üìçPalermo parks for running and clearing my head

My Biggest Mistake (So You Don't Make It)

I signed a lease without understanding the garant√≠a system. I thought my Irish bank references would work. They didn't. I had to pay a 'guarantor service' $500 to basically vouch for me. Read about this stuff BEFORE you sign anything.

Remote work challengesCultural adjustmentMa√±ana culture navigationBuilding patience
Priya Sharma
London, UK ‚Ä¢ Freelance Writer
9 min read
San Telmo6 months in BADefensa near Plaza Dorrego
"I came to write a novel. Instead, I'm writing about inflation and economic collapse. The irony isn't lost on me."

Priya moved to Buenos Aires for inspiration and affordable living as a writer. She found both, but also found herself navigating an economy in crisis, learning to think in multiple currencies, and discovering that artistic inspiration sometimes comes from chaos.

The Good
  • ‚Ä¢ I can afford to write full-time here. In London, I needed a day job.
  • ‚Ä¢ San Telmo is like living in a movie. The tango, the street art, the antique shops
  • ‚Ä¢ The literary scene here is incredible - bookstores everywhere
  • ‚Ä¢ I've written more in 6 months than in 2 years in London
The Bad
  • ‚Ä¢ Watching prices change weekly is anxiety-inducing
  • ‚Ä¢ I had to become an amateur economist just to grocery shop
  • ‚Ä¢ The power went out during a deadline. 'Tranqui' doesn't pay my bills
The Reality

You become obsessed with exchange rates. You check the blue dollar rate like other people check Instagram. You know which cuevas give the best rates. You have opinions about stablecoins. This is not normal life.

What I Wish I Knew Before Moving

  • ‚ÜíHave multiple income streams in different currencies. Peso income is worthless.
  • ‚ÜíThe romantic idea of the struggling artist is cute until you're actually struggling.
  • ‚ÜíBring a power bank and download offline maps. Infrastructure fails.

My Monthly Budget (USD)

Rent:$400 USD (room in shared apartment, San Telmo)
Utilities:$25 USD
Food:$250 USD (cooking, cheap empanadas, occasional splurge)
Coworking:$0 (writing in cafes)
Transport:$20 USD
Misc:$100 USD
Total:~$795/month

Where I Hang Out

  • üìçEl Federal for writing and coffee
  • üìçMercado de San Telmo for cheap lunches
  • üìçThe feria on Sundays for people-watching
  • üìçAny quiet corner of a milonga for tango inspiration

My Biggest Mistake (So You Don't Make It)

I didn't bring enough cash and I didn't understand the blue dollar. I was using my UK card at the official rate for my first month. I basically paid double for everything. Learn about the parallel exchange rates BEFORE you spend a penny.
